captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: My name
is Mike Musto.

Each week I travel the country
with the goal of showcasing

the best and baddest muscle
cars and hot rods around.

Every car has a past and
every owner a story.

welcome to the world
of "Big Muscle".
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: Magazine
clippings.
Tools.
Repair manuals.
Photographs.
Telephone numbers.
Scale models.
A differential.

And, of course, an
extra engine.

These are just some of the
things we found when we

visited the garage
of Chuck Rust.

Now, on their own these items
wouldn't raise an eyebrow to

most folks, but collectively and
in this setting they set

the stage for one of the most
die-hard car guys we've
featured to date.

The difference, however, between
Chuck and the rest of

the automotive populous though,
is that not only has

he been racing his whole life,
both on two wheels are four,

but he had the innate ability
and understanding to see how

the Chevrolet Corvair, a car
once deemed unsafe at any

speed, can not only be improved
upon, but with some

extra hard-core modifications
built into one hell of a
performance machine.
CHUCK RUST: It all started--

I had an El Camino and I was
over in Manhattan Beach, and
it had a healthy 350 in it.

And I'm coming off of the light,
and right next to me is

a white Corvair,
which I'd never
even thought of Corvairs.
I always had big Chevy's.

And so I pulled ahead
and we're going,
kind of, up this uphill.
He pulls up next to me--

and this is the key thing
that's really got me--

he looked over at me and pulled
right up next to me and

turned a 90 degree and went
down a side street.
And I never forgot that.

I pull up in my van
at this party and
there's the white Corvair.

And I got out and
I looked at it.

And I'm like, Oh my God
I've got to talk to
this guy, you know?

I put the word out, and out into
the universe too, and in

two weeks this car-- a friend
of mine called me and said,

hey, I got, I got a car
you got to look at it.

And it was a complete
basket-case.
It was all apart.

The guy had blown the
transmission, but he rebuilt

it and put it together
and stuff.

Anyway, long story short, I'd
sold my dirt bike for

$2,500.00 How much did he want
for this car in its form?
It was perfect.

MIKE MUSTO: Sometimes we come
across a car that we look at

and we go, I--I-- got
to film that.
We have to film that.

So a couple weeks ago, Zach and
I were walking through a

car show and we happened
upon this.

We are right now behind the
wheel of a 1965 Chevrolet
Corvair Crown Corsair.
This is something that I--

I-- you know, I've read about
them, but I've never actually

seen before until we kind
of stumbled upon this.

What Chuck has done is actually
taken one of the

worse cars in history, and I'll
be honest with you, made

it one of the coolest
that we've driven to
date on "Big Muscle".

Think about it like this, the
flat 6-engine that used to

hang over the rear wheels is
gone, and in its place is a

mid-mounted, 283 cubic engine
V8 that revs to the moon and
sounds glorious.
now I driven a Corvair before.

In fact, I raced one, the
24-hour of the Lemons.

It was the biggest POS I've
ever driven, to the point

where you would step on the
brake and you would turn a

left at the same time because
the car just pulled to the
right so bad.
This car--

holy crap did he sort
this thing out.

I mean, you can bring it,
down shift, right?

Pitch it into the corner and
then just throttle it around.

You've got no power steering,
so you feel
everything coming through.

And rolling, and just let
it rev and rev and rev
and rev. Oh my God.

Now you've got to realize, it's
not a massive, massive
horse-power car.

I, mean it's only about 310
horse-power, but it's the way

you can utilize that power that
makes this car so good.

He's figured out the handling
of this car.

He's figured out the way
to make it work.

He's-- he's dialed it in
to a point where I--

I could be driving a Porsche
Cayman right
now, and I got news--

I wouldn't be having
as much fun.

This car is a visual and mental
assault to the senses.

I've got this massive
race mirror up here.

I can see everything
that's going on.

Not only that, I can hear
everything that's going on

because of the big
V8 behind me.
And holy [BLEEP]
is it unbelievable.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

CHUCK RUST: There are probably
2,500 kits made.

And on-- and I was thinking last
night I'm just going to
say 50 in the--

maybe 100 in the United
States running.

And there's a lot more
that aren't running.

And then there's some in Europe,
and there's some in
Australia, some in Sweden.

They're all over the world,
but there's not very many
running and that are set up.
[ENGINE CAR ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: All right, so let's
talk a little bit about

what this car actually
looks like.

First of all, the mountain
design is gorgeous.

This is a really, really
slick looking car.

In stock form, you know, you
might, kind of, pass it up,

but the way Chuck has
it done its great.

From the gold paint to the
black accents, the little

skulls that run across
the rocker panel.

All these little touches
lend to a really
aggressive look and feel.

This back panel in back
of me is made out
of a composite that--

it's not going to scratch and at
the same time it's totally
vented to let heat out.

You know, you guys are looking
at me right now and I'm--I'm
wedged in this thing.

I mean, I got, you know,
basically, I can shift if I
wanted to underneath my leg.

That's how tight I
am in this car.
But I feel--
I feel good.
You know what I mean?

And the cool part is like, I
look in my review mirror and I

see this big massive
air cleaner on
the top of the motor.

And every time I hit the motor
I can see it tweak like this.
[ENGINE CAR ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: Guys you've
got to remember
I'm driving a Corvair.

This is the car that Ralph
Nader tried to get killed

because he was like, it's
unsafe at any speed.

What Chuck has done to this car
has not only made it good,
he's made it brilliant.
And, oh my God, does it show.

I mean, take it, drop it in--
oh my God, oh, I'm in first,
drop it down into second.

Throw it in, let it rev.
Let it wind, let it
wind, let it wind.
Shift up.
Aw man, does it work.

And it works really,
really good.
[ENGINE CAR ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: As far as balance
and everything, it's near--
near perfect balance.

It's a little bit heavier in
the back, and it's got I
believe a 55 45.
And I put--

I had to put big brakes
on the front.

I put Corvette disc brakes
from like a '78 Corvette.

The car's light, and so it
hauls it right down.

Sway bars front and rear,
which are available, but

obviously a lot of these things
are harder to find now.

And it's got eight inch rims
with 245/50-15 on the back and
seven inch on the front.

Now mind you, that's coming up
from 13s because stock is 13.
Some add 14s.

So, you know, a 15 inch
wheel and then going--

and they were, I think,
six inches wide--
so we've widened it.

We've got a 225/50-15 with an
eight inch print in the front
and a nine inch in the back.

It's got nine inches
of rubber.
I've lowered it.

I've cut the coils and
got it-- got it down.

And so that-- that seemed
to be the hot seller.
[ENGINE CAR ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: If there's a theme
that goes on throughout this

car I'd have to say
it's balance.

You know, he's gone through
great pains in his garage by

the way, to make sure
that this was a very
well-balanced car.

Everything was done for a
reason, be it the large

race-style mirrors so you can
see all around you, from the

pressure of the clutch, to the,
you know, to the bump

stop on the bottom of the
clutch, to the gauge package,

to the mirrors, to everything
that's gone into this car to

make it Chuck's own personal
idea of what the perfect
Corvair is.

Now, you know, you've got to
remember also, that this is

the car that came before
the Chevrolet Camaro.

So you've got to wonder well,
could this have been, if

Chevrolet had maybe done a
Corvair in a mid-engine, if

this would have been the
Corvette, or kind of, the, you

know, the next rendition
of the Corvette?

Could they have gone
to a mid-engine
if it worked better?
I don't know.

Little questions like that
always, kind of,
spark the old psyche.
[ENGINE CAR REVING]

I don't think anybody would
ever consider a Corvair a

muscle car until they
see the episode.

You know, because nobody says,
like, you know, hey, I'm going
to go hot rod a Corvair.

Yeah, that doesn't
happen to often.
[ENGINE CAR REVING]

CHUCK RUST: People see this
car and they go, oh my God

they've got the motor
in the back seat.

Nine out of ten guys go,
that's where Chevy
should have put it.

That's what they should
have done.

And maybe someday the Corvette
will be that, but to right
now, this is what it is.
Yeah.

MIKE MUSTO: Sometimes we come
across cars that not only
surprise us, but inspire us.

They go against the grain of
conventional wisdom, and they

asked the question
of, what if?

This Crown Corsair right
here is such a car.

And even though it's not the
fastest car we've ever driven

on "Big Muscle" it's
a rule-breaker.

And that's something well-- that
this show is all about.

You know, V8 engine,
mid-section, gone is the rear
flat-6 motor.

It does everything the way
that owner Chuck Ross
wanted it to do.

So guys, as always, thank
you for joining us.

And we will absolutely
see you again next
week on "Big Muscle".

-Hey, that sounded
pretty good.
Yeah!
MIKE MUSTO: Yahtzee!
-Yahtzee.
[LAUGHTER]
-Good?
Do you want to try one more?

MIKE MUSTO: I could do another
one but I'm OK.
[LAUGHTER]
-I think that works.
-All right.
-OK.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Mid-Engine Crown Corvair: Porsche Cayman Fighter - /BIG MUSCLE

comments.text:
Evert time I watch one of BIG MUSCLE, it always puts a big smile on my 
face.﻿
comments.author: CompletelyPro\Mercy - EDITOR

comments.text:
Man, I just do not know about this car. It looks amazing, however, taking 
out the air cooled motor ruins it IMO.﻿
comments.author: Joseph Kyler

comments.text:
I'm a MOPAR guy but the 2 Corvairs I had I liked. these could have become 
corvette killers . mine was a comfy ride.﻿
comments.author: Jim Braun

comments.text:
I had a 62 monza 4spd. put is a big bore kit , log ram , AFB 4 BBL carb 
ieco quick shift link and steering , koni shocks and springs. for a corvair 
it was really good and fun to drive. Drove it from Long beach Calif. to 
Daytona Florida , approximately 52 hours for 2,700 miles .﻿
comments.author: Jim Braun

comments.text: I want this car.﻿
comments.author: MIKE MAYERAN

comments.text:
+Manny Decastro I still have quick turn shortened steering arms if anyone 
wants em just pay for shipping they`re yours
comments.author: Franz Klammer II

comments.text:
+MIKE MAYERAN Always wanted to build one of these I bought a crown VW 
adaptor and 3bbl porsche webers sold it with a 140 hp engine to a guy with 
a GT40 kit car...I`ve owned many my favorite was a 65 corsa turbo
comments.author: Franz Klammer II

comments.text: +Manny Decastro Not in my budget.....lol
comments.author: MIKE MAYERAN

comments.text:
Mike when I seen this episode I said the same thing. I joined the Corvair 
club of America , and last night I pulled a 1965 Monza into my driveway 
that was 4 1/2 hours away. I have just started my goal. I recommend you do 
the same. We ain't getting younger.
comments.author: Manny Decastro

comments.text:
Corvair was supposed to be an Economy car to compete with VW...  but the 
Turbo Spider was rather fast I should think? ﻿
comments.author: Mark H

comments.text: What's the weight ratio on front to back 50/50 with that v8?﻿
comments.author: martin750hp

comments.text: he said in the video. Its about 55/45 rear bias.
comments.author: WeStandToFight

comments.text:
The original Corvair actually could generate more lateral G on a skidpad 
than most other U.S. Cars of the time. Once it let go, the handling 
characteristics were different to what most persons were used to. Nothing 
like a bit of cast iron upfront to induce a bit of under steer. ﻿
comments.author: bunning63

comments.text:
Well THAT is unique ! American muscle that can actually go around corners 
at speed !﻿
comments.author: Richard Jarvis

comments.text: El Camino, the gateway cruck!﻿
comments.author: ash man

comments.text:
the 283 chevy v8 is one of the best engines ever built out of the factory. 
 Forged rods, forged crank, throw in some forged pistons.  Top off with 
some built heads and roller rockers and titanium valves, mine revs to 7.5k 
no problem.  Now it is only 340hp but it would put a smile on your face 
every time you rev it.  Backed by a rock crusher 4 speed its a beast. 
 Currently residing in a vega it tears the corners and strip.  ﻿
comments.author: bdogman666

http://youtu.be/3hKn8idEaZE﻿

comments.text: This is a totally ridiculous custom car. I love it!!﻿
comments.author: repairdrive

comments.text:
Guys, you all can hate, but the owner built this car for him, not for the 
likings of other people. I'd love to drive this car and see what it's like 
to drive.﻿
comments.author: Andres Garcia

comments.text:
If you wanna use up a months worth of adrenaline in a couple minutes, this 
car's for you. Visceral
comments.author: Dave Decker

comments.text:
And now Chevy is designing a mid engine corvette. What we have here, is a 
revolutionist.﻿
comments.author: obliviousfafnir01

comments.text: Beautiful and visceral.﻿
comments.author: BorisW150

comments.text:
Many here ragging on this 'Vair but this build is great. I could never get 
over the 90 degree fan belt on the flat six but guess properly done they 
were effective in the sand digger category, however the second styling was 
killer....like one of these in silver...﻿
comments.author: silvernail6

comments.text: 10:56 Cool cats don't look at the camera. Awesome car by the way!﻿
comments.author: Seventaiji

comments.text: 4:49 Anybody know what kind of differential it has?﻿
comments.author: David James

comments.text:
Okay  here's the deal on that. Chevy interpretation of the VW porsche 
transaxle except the bell housing was cast integrally with the engine block 
instead of the transmission as on the VW Had its own internals until the 
180hp spyder proved too powerful for the trannie, they then adapted the 
Saginaw 4 speed box. Car was originally available with 3 speed 4 speed 
manual and a 2 speed "powerslide' automatic transmission. the mid engine 
conversion was possible because the air cooled engine spun counter 
clockwise so the V8 application involved turning the trannie 180 degrees. 
Here's some to p.o. the Porsche snobs, Porsche helped with the design of 
the Corvair motor!
comments.author: giantgeoff

comments.text:
+Philopho saur Yes, a short custom input shaft made for the later "Saginaw" 
four speed. The Crown conversion. Anything more than an old small block 
Chevy will break the transaxle. Reportedly a big block Chevy would give you 
ONE run at the 1/4 mile.
If you root around, you still may be able to find some close ratio 
gearsets, altho I doubt it.
Honestly, when you're done swapping in the engine you're faced 
with---mediocre drum brakes, mediocre steering, mediocre suspension......by 
todays standards.
This used to be a super bad-ass conversion back in the 60s.
It really is just retro hotrodding now. 50 years back stuff.
Still pretty cool 'tho.
comments.author: TwoLotus2

comments.text: +Dave Decker, with a forward input though?
comments.author: David James

comments.text: Stock Corvair. Prolly with beef up guts
comments.author: Dave Decker

comments.text:
I like this idea but to be honest I want to but a complete front suspension 
and cradle setup from a supercharged Buick Park Avenue into this car. It 
should balance out fine and leave the rear seat, I've seen these V-8 
conversions done where there was a bunch more leg room in the front. This 
car should have had some attention used in finishing the inside of the 
engine compartment. Please get rid of the CROWN sticker at the top of the 
windshield and most of the black accents. It would be so much more sinister!
It's a cool car thought and while I beat it up it's still way better than 
my car! Wanna sell it? I can't pay much 'cause somebody done put da rong 
moter in it!(all bad spelling on purpose!)﻿
comments.author: Bob Ordewald

comments.text:
How is this one of the worst cars ever? they sold over 1.8 million. Also 
the Yenko stinger Corvair won tons of races. This is a cool one of a kind 
GM car, air cooled boxer engine. It deserves more credit. IMO﻿
comments.author: William G

comments.text:
+WeStandToFight 
The little European fords were a delight to drive Exuberantly. EVER HAD A 
CHANCE TO DRIVE A cORTINIA
comments.author: 246spyder

comments.text:
+PacificCircle1
Production of the Corvair began in 1959 but they were sold for the 1960 
model year.... Just like how Chevrolet began production of the Impala in 
1957 but sold them for the 1958 model year.
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+246spyder Nadir did hurt it's sales. I did not know Corvairs were sold 
back in 1959, wow! The American appetite was, in general, for bigger, nicer 
or faster cars. Trucks, not so much. My '69 stepside was built bare bones. 
425,000 miles on it.
comments.author: PacificCircle1

comments.text:
+PacificCircle1
No, he did not kill the car, progress called "mustang" finished it. The 
Corvair was just past its zenith when the Ford Phenomena hit the streets 
ready to feed the masses, period.

I loved my then new '63 Spyder (still have the emblems), but its time was 
over. It lasted from '59 to '69 and had a great run, nothing of which to be 
ashamed. Nothing matched it no mater how hard the others tried.
 
It was beat gracefully by a car that fulfilled the new desires of a up and 
coming young generation. It was always a tad light in the HP department and 
not a lot of hop-up things were out there for the enthusiast. Chevy had 
taken it as far as was practical engine-wise, Don Roe, Yenko, Fitch Sprint, 
and all the others had really done their best, but alas and alack it was 
time to move on.

GM had nothing in its lineup or even on the drawing board to go against the 
popular Mustang.

Yes they had the Catalina 2+2 421, the new '64 GTO (Oh my be still my 
heart) but nothing to match the new "Pony-Car.
The proof was in the pudding when it out sold everything out there, even 
though it was nothing more than a gussied up Falcon, but who cared it was 
COOL. and just wait for that 289 and all else that followed later.

R.I.P my good friend, you will alway be very close to my heart and in my 
memories. You served me well (ha ha 327 Biscanes you beat with no problem) 
but the future had no place for the likes of you in spite of your great 
performances on the road-tracks, your record holding Pikes Peak runs, Etc.

No, Nader was a paper tiger, when it came pass. Future had no time for the 
old ones, the new Young Turks were coming fast and they would rule until 
the Big Bad Government and Insurance Companies neutered them in the early 
'70s. R.I.P the greatest most affordable beasts to ever roam the 
stoplighted streets of our glory days.
Never again will we see their likes, don't tell me about whats out there 
now, because back then most all could afford an untamed, unbridled monster 
426, 440, 396 ETC, and so many other off the shelf 1320' 12 sec. killers of 
time-traps.

I feel sorry for those of you who will never ever begin experience the 
thrill of them, and much thanks to you who carry on the tradition of 
showing the rest a small sampling of those days and cars.
comments.author: 246spyder

comments.text:
+William G Corvairs were high tech for America at the time. Because they 
had a slightly higher risk of gasoline fire (~20% at max), they were killed 
by Ralph Nadir. The cure was simply mechanical.
comments.author: PacificCircle1

comments.text:
Im from the uk and drive a Ford Fiesta (not to be confused with the 
Festiva, which is a different model), yeah its a small little dinky thing 
with a 1.3litre engine but it gets me places and for a little Eurobox 
Fiesta's have always had the best handling in its class, I'm a ford guy and 
eventually would like to drive a more powerful car, but oldschool.
comments.author: WeStandToFight

comments.text:
+WeStandToFight
I drive a 1996 Saturn SL1, it has power steering and an automatic 
transmission. I've wanted to drive a car without power steering... I think 
it would be a good learning experience, like when I learned to drive a 
stick.
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Alan Schulte Alan, I'm not sure what car you drive but my advice would be 
to buy a non-power steering car and try and live with it. My car granted 
its a 1996 model, doesnt have power steering and my god its difficult to 
maneuver at low speeds and has a tendancy to go light whilst taking fast 
corners. Still, theres nothing like the communication of direct drive, you 
can feel every corner and instinctively know when to lift off or power on 
due to no electronic aids telling you what to do.
comments.author: WeStandToFight

comments.text:
+Brian Tracy
I have not driven an older 911.
I'm kinda a young buck (I'm 19) so I haven't really had any experiences 
with older cars like that. But I've heard and read that what really gave 
the Corvair a bad rep was the spinning out.
I really do like the Corvair, and many other older cars for that matter. 
I'd love to get my hands on some kind of a classic and fix it up myself.
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Alan Schulte Corvairs had very long wheelbases , they would oversteer but 
very predictably and it was easy to control. I've had rear tires blow out 
on a swing axle Vair mid corner and it was no big deal. The 1965-1969 
models would easily outhandle a Corvette... You can get a Corvair to 
oversteer by lifting throttle abruptly mid corner... Have you ever driven a 
911 (before the mid 1990's) ?
comments.author: Brian Tracy

comments.text:
+Sky Marshall I raced swing axle Corvairs... the pre-1965 ones. Nader took 
on Chevy because they were American,, VW , Mercedes , Porsche and others 
had swing axles and even worse problems with axle jacking... Chevy had 
their swing axles under control ,, a Corvair will not "axle jack" or as you 
called it "tuck under" , Nader isn't an engineer and he didn't understand 
the safety precautions that Chevy took, either that or he intentionally 
slandered Chevy. The 1959 (called a 1960) thru 1964 Corvair used special 
shock absorbers with travel limiters ... in 1964 and on the turbo models 
(all years) there were physical limiters on the axles (straps or chains) 
and all 1964's had a flat (transverse) spring at the rear ... The problems 
people had with axle jacking were with cars that had replacement shock 
absorbers ... you see Corvairs shocks were externally identical to "big 
car" Chevy shocks... When you drove into a Midas Muffler for new shocks 
they didn't put the right shocks on,, you got the ones WITHOUT the 
(downward) travel limiters because they were about $2 cheaper and they had 
them in stock... 

Nader slandered Chevy but Chevy didn't fight back because they didn't want 
to have the story in the press any longer than need be. If you want a 
safety related problem with Corvairs ,, try the optional gasoline heater...
comments.author: Brian Tracy

comments.text:
+246spyder SORRY, but I mentioned that he brought up many other subjects in 
his book. If you can't read or comprehend someone's entire comment then 
what is the point in rebutting or arguing with them? In his book, Nader 
stated that the Corvair's swing axle  was subject to "Tuck Under" and that 
instead of using an anti roll bar, to correct this problem, Chevy required 
tire pressures that were outside of the manufacturers recommended tire 
pressure range.

 How is that not  a suspension related issue? Did you read his book or are 
you just talking off the top of your head? It doesn't matter wether Nader 
was right or wrong or if the swing axles were the actual  problem or not. I 
was stating Nader's point of view from his book and you're telling me 
that's not what he said. I clearly stated that the Corvair chapter was only 
a small part of the book and he focused on suspension related and 
consequently tire pressure related issues. I stand by those words.

The true strong or weak points of the Corvair are irrelevant, since my 
comments were directed towards what Nader actually wrote about and not what 
was proven or disproven. In fact, if you took the time to read and 
comprehend my original post, you would have seen that my main point was 
this: Unsafe at any speed is not a book about the Corvair, it's about 
automotive safety in general and the unwillingness of the entire business 
to put safety before profits, period.
comments.author: Sky Marshall

comments.text:
The reason why the Corvair got a bad reputation was because under certain 
circumstances, such as taking a corner too quickly, the Corvair would have 
a tendency to spin out....
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+246spyder actually you're wrong, swing rear axles are archaic and pretty 
dangerous, especially with a big engine mounted over it. In WW2 many a Nazi 
SS officer died driving big rear mounted V8 powered Tatra's with crude 
swing rear axles due to it being so ungainly and rear heavy (which was a 
good thing, the car was nicknamed the Nazi Killer).
comments.author: WeStandToFight

comments.text:
+Sky Marshall
Sorry, but he jumped on a lot of cars and called out the Corvair because of 
its rear weight bias, it had nothing to do with the suspension.
Rear engined cars would be prone to having the rear slide (it's called 
over-steer)
Yep even the top of the line Porsche, a gussied up VW, did it. Yes it could 
catch you off guard if you got a little exuberant
He claimed, incorrectly, that the car was prone to flipping. In dependent 
trials comparing the Corvair to another popular compact, the Ford Falcon. 
They did every maneuver that could think of in order to flip both cars, 
guess which one refused to flip. The Chevy. The car was exonerated in the 
end. Look down a little farther in the comments for my experiences with 
further explanations ofownins and upgrading a '63 Spyder.
Keep in mind that the VW had been on the road since before WWII and had the 
same setup with no serious problems.
comments.author: 246spyder

comments.text:
+Mark H You are correct. Chevy began addressing the problems that Nader 
pointed out, soon after the book came out. As I mentioned in my comments, 
Nader himself pointed out that the aftermarket already was selling 
suspension packages, which solved many of the problems with the Corvair. 
This fact helped to make Nader's point, which was this: The entire auto 
industry was ignoring known safety issues and concerns, which their own 
engineers usually addressed to upper management, only to be ignored, in 
favor of cost savings. It's very unfortunate that most people remember 
Nader's book as an anti-Corvair book. You should check out even a 
description of the book. Nader had this very forward thinking vision of how 
much safer cars could be, that we all take for granted today. Some people 
see the guy as a big buzz killer. But, he really was a visionary and 
 pioneer in automotive safety.
comments.author: Sky Marshall

comments.text:
+Sky Marshall   I think GM greatly improved the Corvair suspension about 
two years before they quit making it..  unless I am confused with Firraro 
which had a similar story ..
comments.author: Mark H

comments.text:
+Mark G Unsafe at Any Speed was not a book about the Corvair. Nader only 
covered the Corvair in 1 out of the 8 chapters in the book. He criticized 
the swing axle design, which in it's stock form on the Corvair was prone to 
"tuck under" as he called it. He was right, when a swing axle set up is 
done incorrectly, the wheels pinch inward. My Baja Bug was raised up and 
you could see a ridiculous amount of camber, from the back.
 
Nader further explained, the Corvair relied on very specific tire 
pressures, which exceeded the tire manufacturer's recommended pressure 
range, to compensate for the lack of the neccessary anti-roll bar, which 
Chevy rejected. But, the tire pressure requirement, band aid fix for the 
tuck under issue, was not made clear to dealers and Corvair owners. He also 
mentioned that Chevy had an unadvertised suspension package and there were 
some aftermarket packages, that adequately solved most of the tuck under 
and suspension issues. In 1965, after Nader's book came out, Chevy 
redesigned the suspension, with a fully independent, four link set up.

Most of the rest of the book focuses several other important, automotive 
safety issues. The book will forever be remembered as a book about the 
Corvair, but it brought up many critical safety issues which had nothing to 
do with the Corvair, such as: "The Second Collision" which occurs when 
unrestrained bodies are allowed to fly around inside of cars that are 
filled with chrome trimmed interiors and all metal dashboards. He talked 
about non collapsable steering columns, unforgiving, sharp instrument 
panels, non-safety glass in windshields, seat belts, door strength, roll 
bars, suicide doors. He talked about how the ornamental bumpers of the time 
would drag a pedestrian under the car, rather than bounce them off. He 
covered the industry focus on stylish design, at the expense of safety. The 
list of subjects goes on.The guy was kind of a hero in my book. He was so 
far ahead of his time, it was ridiculous.
comments.author: Sky Marshall

comments.text: Ralph Nader wrote a book about this car that gave it a bad reputation.

comments.text:
TwoLotus2 - - You are correct.  I thought I knew more than I actually did. 
I had always thought the 64 rear suspension was basically the same as the 
65 thru 69s.  I stand corrected.  
http://www.corvaircorsa.com/handling02.html
comments.author: Jim King

comments.text:
+Jim King 
Swing axle suspension IS a "true" form of independent suspension.  It's 
just one form of independent suspension, and it's basically garbage, IMO.
In 1964, the (still swing axle) Corvair received an auxiliary spring (not a 
camber compensator) added to the rear, that while it supported the weight 
of the car, it did not have any effect on body roll as it was allowed to 
pivot at the center of the car. Chevrolet added an anti-roll bar to the 
front to compensate for the increased body roll caused by the new rear leaf 
spring.
This caused the rear tires to naturally assume a more negative camber 
attitude in the corners, and the front to understeer more. So you could say 
the '64s were half fixed.
 The 1965 -69 Corvairs had what could be called a multilink rear 
suspension--similar to a 63+ Corvette and Jag XK-E.
comments.author: TwoLotus2

comments.text:
The model of Corvair used in this conversion never had 'Swing-Axle rear 
suspension'.  GM replaced the swing axle with true IRS starting with the 
1965 models.  Only the 1960 to 1964 models had the swing axle. 

How many times does that have to be said before it sinks into the 
consciousness of those reading this comment thread ???

Manwithbeard-- The VW DID have trailing arm suspension -- That is NOT what 
determines whether or not it is a 'Swing Axle'.
 
A 'Swing Axle' only has a CV joint at the transmission end of the drive 
axle.  That forces the tire to move in an arch as the suspension moves up & 
down.  It is a form of independent rear suspension.

The IRS system used in Corvairs starting with the 1965 model had CV joints 
at both ends of the drive axles and control arms similar to front 
suspension so that the tires moved straight up and down and the tire tread 
stayed flat on the road surface.  The stock 1965 thru 1969 Corvairs handled 
BETTER than a race prepped Corvette.
comments.author: Jim King

comments.text:
The Corvair got a multi link IRS in 65.  However, Swing axle rear 
suspensions were quite common on early rear engine cars. Many had it before 
Corvair used it. VW Beetle & Porsche had swing axles, the early 60s Pontiac 
Tempest was a frt engine, but still had a rear trans-axle with swing axle 
rear suspension.
The Corvair was never "Unsafe at any speed". It actually handled BETTER 
than the Corvette of the same era. 
Ralph Nader was an idiot, sh_t for brains lawyer that didn't know anything 
about cars, but did know how to make a public stink & get publicity.  IMO, 
Nader should have been shot when he first opened his stupid mouth.

never even held a drivers license. Those are facts. So, I don't know where 
you got the idea that his daughter died in one but you are incorrect about 
that.
comments.author: Flat6

comments.text: That explains it then.

comments.text:

and drives nice, gets a lot of looks too

you guys have to make a video about that cummins rat rod!! would be so bad

comments.author: Göktuğ Erol

comments.text:
THAT IS THE MOST BADASS CAR EVER MADE IT LOOKS LIKE IT CAN PUNCH YOU IN THE 
FACE﻿
comments.author: SonOfClevelandTV

comments.text: This thing is actually so sexy holy fuck﻿
comments.author: Jonathan Blancas

comments.text:
Corvair - - UNSAFE ??  When did you start parroting Ralph Nadar ?? To call 
the Corvair one of the worst cars in history is just plain IGNORANT! ! The 
Corvair was always a GREAT car, even the early swing axle jobs.  A Stock 
Corvair would corner better than a race prepped Corvette.  Of Course they 
could be improved on, but they were damned good to begin with.  I only 
owned one, a 1965 Corsa 140/4speed, and that thing was like a slot car 
going through curves & the straight line performance wasn't that bad 
either.  I loved the oversteer.  Cars that plowed were what I didn't like.﻿
comments.author: olmon11

comments.text:
Valid points David , but from a grassroots view, it's the definition of 
what Hot Rodding means. Would I prefer a stronger trans axle- yes. But go 
on the v-8 directory and see what many guys modified and improved on to 
make this a very competitive ride with vehicles much more expensive. And if 
no frills turns you on, well this is it. I build 20's-30's hot rods and 
these Corvair builders actually have it tougher because of the lack of 
aftermarket availability . So much is old school one off parts. Which leads 
to me wanting to buy a turnkey or project, you just can't go by word of 
mouth or pictures. You have travel to use your five senses ( plus common 
sense). Bottom line love them and want to own one.....
comments.author: Manny Decastro

comments.text:
+David Massieux
 You just go from making one stupid statement right into making another.  
Go tell your Momma to slap you.  You have no business commenting on the 
suspensions or roadability of any automobile. 
BTW, I am certified in steering, braking and suspension systems for 
automobiles and light trucks.  I spent almost 40 years working in the auto 
repair industry and I have done a fair amount of road racing & I set up my 
own cars.  I KNOW what works, whats good & what isn't.  The Corvair was 
GOOD.  Even the Swing axle version was good.  The independent rear 
suspension that they put on it from 1964 thru 1969 was just better.
comments.author: Jim King

comments.text:
Um, that was not what you were implying in your comment. Your comment was 
about swing axles. I responded by giving you some information about early 
vs. late model Corvairs suspension and some testing regarding the Corvair. 
You seemed to be lacking knowledge in that area and perhaps you think that 
a Lawyer without a drivers license, nor a degree in engineering might know 
more about cars than the folks who build them. Perhaps you could do some 
research on how many cars utilize swing axle suspension other than 60-63 
Corvairs and let me know your thoughts on how dangersous they are. Anyway, 
back on track here, my response was not about crumple zones, air bags, 
ani-lock brakes. As far as 2000+ Cars you can't really do an apples to 
apples comparison can you? I can tell you this, I know of a gentleman who 
was rear ended in a Corvair, was at a dead stop and hit from behind at 
55mph. Happened three weeks ago and he is fine. Know of another gentleman 
who suffered the same and another who survived a head on collision in one. 
Are they safer? As far as technology in comparison to new cars, then of 
course not. But as I said earlier, that is not what your statement was 
about.
comments.author: Flat6

comments.text: So you're saying that a Corvair is safer than for example a 2000+ car?
comments.author: David Massieux

comments.text:
You are the one who is showing ignorance here. First the early generation 
Corvair (with swing axle) was the first and only car to be deemed SAFE. The 
NHTSA put in place by Ralph Naders urging, heavily tested the EARLY model 
Corvair in 1972 against the other cars of the period and found it to be 
Safe. It is very easy to look these FACTS up. Second, olmon11 is referring 
to a LATE model Corvair that does not have Swing Axle suspension. It has 
full IRS! 65 and up Corvairs handle extremely well. 9 division 
Championships in SCCA against Porsches, Ferraris, etc. Check out a Yenko 
Stinger! Come watch a Corvair at an Autocross! Don't slam someone as making 
an ignorant statement when you clearly know nothing about Corvairs!
comments.author: Flat6

comments.text:
To call it a great car is as ignorant, a car with a swing axle IS dangerous 
on road, adaptative camber depending on the compressions is just plain 
stupid for the commoners. Add to that the lack of precision due to soft 
suspension control, and you've got a good car to cruise but bad to find the 
limit. So YOU liked it, but it doesn't make it a good car in the eyes of 
physics and safety, it makes it something that lives in your heart, and 
that makes for biased opinions. I'm the first one to love Chevrolets, but 
this one would be today's stock mustang or camaro, not a sports car, just a 
very enjoyable car.
comments.author: David Massieux

comments.text:
The Corvair wasn't unsafe. The problem was that the engine were in the back 
over the axle and made it over steer. This was when all other american cars 
had a big heavy engine in the front of the car and thus made it under 
steer. So the Americans were not used to cars that over steered and it then 
got a bad reputation. A lot of European cars had the same layout, like the 
Porsche and other small European sports cars and they were not seen as 
unsafe because the Europeans were used to cars that over steered. ﻿
comments.author: Metin Erdinc

comments.text:
It was way more than under steering that caused problems. The rear swing 
arms folded under when pitched into a corner. Unlike the Porsche or VW, 
there was no "toss it & catch it". My '64 Spyder was decambered to the max 
& it was still a bloody mess to try & corner.  The 2nd. generation was a 
dream. In fact, the Corsa's were the design as originally conceived. But GM 
being GM, they needed to make it as cheap as they dared.
comments.author: James Hines

comments.text:
+Jim King
Exactly right, weight distribution is the biggest factor.   
However it is quite possible to make front engined cars with 50/50 - like 
BMW, and I am sure most of the mid-engine exotics are shooting for 50/50.
Once you have 50/50, the rest of the suspension setup is much easier and 
handling is so much nicer
comments.author: Brynn Rogers

comments.text:
+Tom Berry
 Over and under steer can be affected to a degree with suspension set-up, 
but weight distribution is the major contributor to that tendency.  Front 
engined cars inherently understeer while rear engined cars inherently 
oversteer.
comments.author: Jim King

comments.text:
I get where you're coming from but the oversteer/understeer is dialed in 
through the suspension setup, usually with through the swaybars. But yes 
the public liked "traditional" front engined  vehicles and the 
manufacturers designed them to plow understeer rather than snap oversteer.

Very interesting episode, i didnt know the corvair existed untill today.
comments.author: Tom Berry

comments.text:
Oversteer was only a problem for people that couldn't drive - - I owned 
other rear engined cars besides Corvair & they were all great for road 
racing just the way they came stock.  When I got into driving front engined 
cars I had to do numerous modifications to make them handle well enough to 
road race &  compete with stock rear engined cars.

This Crown conversion makes the Corvair a Mid-engined car & the weight 
moving forward make the cornering more neutral than with the rear engine, 
but I highly doubt that it would corner any faster, if as fast.
comments.author: olmon11

comments.text:
My old roomie and I built one of these around 35 years ago. The Crown kit 
consisted of a sub-frame, motor mounts, cooling system components, and a 
special input shaft so the stock transaxle could be used. A lot of 
fabrication was left to the owner, which is undoubtedly why a lot of them 
never got finished. Mine had a 327/365 HP solid-lifter `Vette engine, with 
a 3.55 Posi. It only weighed 2700 pounds, and embarrassed LOTS of flashy 
muscle cars....  :-)﻿
comments.author: Blackwaterdogs

comments.text:
Why don't I know what comprised a "Crown kit"? The lack of technical detail 
is inexcusable considering you mention three times how it's not the most 
powerful car you've featured and waste a lot of air saying nothing.  The 
camera views of the differential beg several questions of how the engine 
swap was done and now I have to go look it up.
And how do you not know what to call a Wink mirror?﻿
comments.author: Al Terego
